reviewText: The Detail is an episodic point and click crime drama, set in a modern American city infested with gangs and crime everywhere. This story has you follow the lives of two very different characters: Detective Reggie Moore, an older maverick cop with a problem with the politics of law enforcement, and Joe Miller, a crook gone legit trying to hold down a job and a family being forced back into the criminal world. Together they must find out information about a homicide that could just bring the city into chaos.The game opens in a black and white graphic novel panel style for the different scenes; no ambient sounds plays just a fantastic gripping score which adds more depth than you would expect to this gritty drama. After the prologue the player is greeted with a full colour comic style screen, and a neat little page corner appears on the bottom of the screen to indicate the next scene. Having no dialogue audio might be a bit of a turn off for folk, but personally I felt it gave me more involvement in the character development.It also features “the board” a detectives best friend, a cork board with all the characters you encounter with a bio about them and notes on any encounter you have with them.The characters feel slightly “80’s cop movie”, with the maverick detective and your good guy by-the-books partner, resembling a young Danny Glover. The characters have such good friend/partner banter between them that has you enjoying all of the dialogue given to you. I must commend the fantastic story, it gets really heavy-duty at points were you are having to co-operate with criminals to save his victim; You just feel so dirty and angry as you are giving him a deal. This is the sign of a truly gripping story when you actually feel raw emotion towards characters and situations.While the game has no audio when it comes to, well anything really. The only audio in this is the background music, mainly a solo piano playing chilling slow music with off keys and giant bursts of hard hitting dramatic music. All cinematic sounds in the game are represented by old fashion comic noises “thump”, “crack”, “ra-ta-ta-ta-ta” etc. It is a clever way to get across impacts in a far more visually and feeling as someone is elbowed in the face.What makes the gameplay so fantastic is that it feels like an old school adventure game got a slight polish. With the use of Quick Time Events the story is brought into a more modern vibe, which just adds to the immersion as the stress builds during those QTE something fierce. Episode 1 does exactly what it should, grabs you right from the get-go and leaves you desperate for more. It is a truly captivating story, gruesome and pretty heavy-duty, but captivating nonetheless.

reviewText:
The Detail is an episodic game about a veteran detective and an ex-criminal trying to solve a murder and investigate other criminal activity. They won’t do this as a team; you’ll control both independently. The developer states that this experience was made for fans of HBO’s hit series The Wire and Telltale Games’ The Walking Dead. Obviously, these weren’t the only inspirations and the game is actually meant to be played by anyone who’s even remotely interested in it, or by anyone who’s interested in adventure games in general. Read on to see what I think of it.

In the first episode (called Where The Dead Lie) you first control a veteran detective who’s looking into a murder case. During the game you’ll eventually swap with an ex-criminal who’s forced into helping out with the investigations. I’m not going to tell you more about the story; as a story-driven adventure game it’s important that you experience as much of it by yourself.
During this first episode you’ll be clicking on several points of interest. These are all clearly shown with a yellow border around them, so there’s no pixel hunting involved like many, many other adventure games out there. Click on a border and you’ll learn more about it. Looking/reading is your primary action when investigating an object or person and sometimes it’s possible to switch between actions by scrolling the mouse. You’ll be able to easily pick things up and talk to people this way.
By playing you’ll also be able to unlock character information of people you meet and even though it’s not necessary to collect them all (or at all, really) I can see people replaying the game just to complete their ‘collection’. It’s not quite similar to The Wolf Among Us’ fairytale creatures, but in a way it is.
The puzzles are made with a casual audience in mind, meaning anyone can pick up and play this game without having too much trouble completing it. To be honest I doubt that there are people that won’t be able to finish it at all; in fact, I don’t think you can even call them puzzles. It’s all so subtle that it all feels part of the story, which is good, but if I’m going to play as an investigator I want to be challenged, even if it’s for a little bit. In this case the gameplay is very similar to The Walking Dead, which was basically non-existent. It would be nice to see future episodes have a little more depth, but I also hope they’ll keep the gameplay consistent. Otherwise it might just get messy.
So, the gameplay adds nothing new to the genre but still, what is there works as far as the story is concerned.

The graphics, unfortunately, are a bit of a mixed bag. The black and white comic book-like graphics are done extremely well. In fact, these are just excellent and if the entire game would’ve been made with this style in mind it would’ve been one pretty game. But for some reason (maybe budgetary or artistic reasons) the game uses several art styles, which gives the game an inconsistent look.
One of the things that comes to mind here are the portraits (i.e. conversations). These just aren’t very pretty (putting it a bit more mildly here), and overall they kind of distract from the game.
The environments and characters (in this case not the portraits) on the other hand get the job done, but the characters could benefit from some extra animations.
There’s no voice acting in the game, just text. Of course, there is music; this is very moody and atmospheric, and while it doesn’t make voice acting obsolete, it didn’t make me miss it either.
I agree with the choice (?)  of not using any kind of voice acting; if you have a small budget you don’t want to ruin the immersion with poor and/or cheap voice acting.

For a first episode The Detail has an average length. It took me somewhere between 60-90 minutes to finish it. Clearly it isn’t very long but you can replay the game again and make different choices that will affect the story. I suspect the consequences will be even more obvious during some of the later episodes. I thought the length was good. It was long enough to keep me interested in the story and short enough for the gameplay to become too shallow.

The Detail isn’t quite there yet when it comes to being a classic, but at this stage it’s too early to tell how the story will even unfold. There isn’t much known about the rest of the episodes, except for the fact that the entire game will consist of five of them. There aren’t any release dates so we’ll just have to wait and see. I personally expect an episode to be released every two months, but that’s just me guessing. In any case, The Detail is an interesting game that’s extremely light on the puzzles but it is its story that actually makes me want to keep playing. The first episode ends with a nice cliffhanger and I’m anxious to see and know what will happen next. Now if that isn’t a compliment, I don’t know what is.

Great graphic novel visual style, decent soundtrack, and intriguing mature story. That's what The Detail has to offer.

It takes about an hour and a half to finish the first episode, but you can also squeeze about 4 hours out of it if you plan on going for 100% achievements, at least that's how long it took me. reviewText:
Although I currently don't recommend buying this game, read on to find out why:

The Detail is an indie crime-thriller adventure game using a motion comic aesthetic. It's very nice. The story and characters might come off as a little cliche, but the amount of detail that's gone into the police investigation side of things makes the experience fairly immersive. I played through Episode 1 twice in order to see just how much player choice mattered. There are many gameplay similarities to the Telltale adventure games, though choice in Telltale is nearly nonexistent (it's an illusion). It's hard to make that conclusion with The Detail from a single Episode, but choosing much different approaches certainly led to different situations coming up. Not drastically, but the narrative wobbled about in different ways before re-converging to the main plot thread. From a technical stand point, the game ran without issues on my computer.

Having said all of this mostly positive stuff, why do I not recommend the game? Basically, game length, and bang for buck. There just isn't much here. With my play time above, I was able to do Episode 1 from start to finish twice, and I wasn't even rushing things. The police investigation pickings were detailed, yes, but it had barely gotten started. I still felt like we were in the character introduction stage and the Episode ended. To put a number on it, you can beat Episode 1 in about 40 minutes, which quite a bit shorter than, say, the Telltale games (which are also quite short, but usually on the order of 2 hours).

As of the writing of this review, there is an Episode 1 and an Episode 2. I KNOW for a fact there's no chance the story can resolve itself, or get particularly deep, with one more episode of the same length as Episode 1. Also, $7 for 40 minutes is a little on the steep end. For my part, I'm going to wait until more episodes are released so I can experience the entire story.

There's something good here, and the developers have done a good job with what there is, but there needs to be... more. More... Detail.

Like The Walking Dead and The Wolf Among Us, the choices you make will have an effect on the story (and what achievements you earn) and for this reason definitely has replay value. There are multiple profiles to make use of too for saving those extra playthroughs.

I really enjoyed this, enough so to go straight back in after my first play to try different choices (and to try to get those achievements I didn't get first time round). The story and characters developed well enough to keep me interested and wanting more.

I also like the comic book style graphics, they are done really well - especially the black and white scenes.

This is just episode one and I am very much looking forward to episode two to see how the story unfolds. I think this has a lot of potential to be right up there with the Telltale games.

If you are a fan of the recent Telltale games, crime stories or the comic book style it's definitely worth checking out.

I love it.

I skimmed through some other reviews here and I get the impression some people come into the game with the wrong thing in mind. That's not their fault, everything has it's demographic. This is quite similar to a choose your own adventure, but with fantastic art and interactivity that makes it much more satisfying. The story is good enough that it sticks with you. Like a decent short novel or something. It's not an action game, or even a puzzle game. It's a story, an experience.

The first episode has a great climax and ending, and left me wanting more immediately. The ending of the second was quite sudden to me, and I was a little bit disappointed.

The art in the second isn't as nice in my view. I'm not an artist, but I feel like some of the art used was a draft that ended up as the final piece due to deadlines. There was also some mismatch in the characters depictions in different areas of the game. Character X in a scene sometimes looked different once they were in a conversation and at the forefront of the screen. One officer was wearing a different outfit. I think one persons skin colour changed. Mostly it seemed to be different interpretations of the same character. It's a shame, because the first episode had art that really impressed me, that I could stare at for ages. Staring at the art of the second mainly brought inconsistencies to mind.

There were also several glitches I experienced with episode 2. My save game wasn't used initially and sometimes the characters in scenes would walk in areas they wern't meant to (like the roof), and I see others had more issues too. The developers have released several updates addressing all the known issues, provided steps to remedy problems, and are generally active in the steam discussions.

Overall I think episode 1 is AMAZING and episode 2 was rushed, but good nonetheless. Realise small dev teams don't have the luxury of being able to extend development time indefinitely. Bills have to be paid.

I absolutely recommend both episodes if my first paragraph describes something you could enjoy (story game, not action game, etc). Reward good developers.

It's worth nothing that the game is short. My 4 hour playtime was me taking my time, though I havn't replayed with different choices as some people do. I was satisfied with what I got from this and clearly the length of the game is limited by what is feasible with the type of the game (art HEAVY), and the manpower of the developers.

With context, some leniency for circumstances and such, 8.5/10?
Compared to a perfect game, 7.5/10?

The Detail is a pretty good game. Heavily focused on the story and the characters in the game, and not so much on the puzzles, at least in this first episode.
You play as a three different characters in a city with increasing crime wave:
Kate - the rookie police officer, Reggie - the old and salty detective and Joe - a man with a family and a criminal past, that's catching up to him.
The story is really the strong point of the game. There is no voice acting, and if there was any, this would really look like a well made AAA title. The object of interest are easily visible, plus there is a key you can use to highlight them, with no penalty (or non that I have found out yet), so you should have no problem, figuring out your options. The choices you take, do already change the story in this episode (can't really say more about that without spoilers) and probably in future ones too, and they definitely change the achievements you get - so I would guess, you need at least 3 playthroughs to get them all.
I find the music and the strong language really fitting well with the story and the whole mood of the game and all that noir comic book style. The character animation may use some love, but then again there is not much movement around, because of the comic book style. Also, I would really like if the game doesn't have to spin up all my hard drives every time before it starts, it's REALLY getting on my nerves.
The first episode may look a bit short, but if you check my let's plays - it's as long as the episode 1 of the Wolf Among Us, so I guess it feels short because the story is good ;) Needless to say it ends up with a cliffhanger, so I can't wait for the next one to come out!

Interesting story, cool dark themes, original aesthetic... and disappointingly short. I literally beat the episode faster than the game's cards dropped, 1.5 hours. Replayed and got all the achievements in a little over two hours.

Thus I'm only half-recommending it. I got this from a bundle so I have no regrets, you decide if it's worth its full price.

The Detail's first episode - Where the Dead Lie - strikes an interesting, if not always perfect, blend between great visual novel elements, replete with comic book stylings and a terrific sense of style, and a slightly more ho-hum game.  As a fan of the modern story-driven adventure game revolution (i.e., The Walking Dead, The Blackwell series, and Yesterday), I wound up liking Where the Dead Lie and hope it grows into the game it has the potential to become.

The first episode focuses around the intertwined stories of a weary detective investigating the suspicious murder of a prominent criminal in the middle of a gangland and that of a reformed criminal just trying to keep his nose clean for his wife and his daughter.  These aren't exactly new archetypes, but they're written well and there's lots of room for the player to play them as good, bad, or somewhere in between.

Throughout the game, the player is presented with several choices for dialogue or action, all of which have repercussions in the ways the people around you react.  My personal favorite was the necessity of playing a cop willing to bend the rules to gain access to a gang member's house.  My boneheaded moves had some real negative effects, ones that left me queasy with the results.

While this episode is mostly about laying the groundwork for the plot and characters, these moral choices lead to some excellent taut moments and a brutal showdown at the end of the episode.  If the game's creators can keep up this kind of intense action and dialogue with a pervasive sense of my actions having some real effects, I'll be absolutely delighted.  That said, some way to replay specific scenes when the player has finished with the episode to see the various outcomes without having to replay the whole game would be terrific.

Just finished the first two episodes and I have to say, I'm very impressed.

I read my fair share of graphic novels so I took to the art style straight away. Exceptionally well done and lovely to look at. The game also feels like a graphic novel as it's choice and dialogue focused; there's no inventory in this game. So you have to think about what your character is going to do and how he's going to respond to each person.

I liked the interface: just hover your mouse cursor over something then use right-click to select between the various options to interact with that thing. Quick, easy and efficient.

There were just enough items in the game to interact with too. Playing as a character in a point-and-click game, I like to get the character's view on an item/their surroundings and Rival Games has managed that here. If it were up to me you'd be able to click on EVERYTHING but then that would take so long that games wouldn't get released.

The characters were developed well in the two episodes we have so far and I'm curious to see where everything goes next. I hope we get the full 5 episodes the game is teasing us with.

My only complaint is just that the second episode is very short. I don't tend to worry too much about getting achievements but I suppose replaying and acting differently will extend the length of the game.

A well done, grown-up interactive graphic novel. Recommended.

The Detail is a beautifully executed mature crime drama that offers meaningful choices and multiple playable main characters with different perspectives. It rewards careful thought and good intuition with choices with logical paths. The characters are deep and compelling, which is amplified by the gripping story - all accomplished with brilliant writing.

The game play is point and click in the vein of Tell Tale's Walking Dead series, and you can tell they took some inspiration in how they balance the pace of the game - there are some really tense moments where you are rewarding by thinking and acting quickly. Considering how much variation there is depending on your choices within the first episode I imagine there will be really great branching in further episodes. The art style is beautiful, some of the art is really beautiful and striking - and some of it seems really amateur, along with the animation, but it all builds the atmosphere amazingly. The music is perfect, it builds the mood without being intrusive. A single playthrough is very short, will take you 1-2 hours, but there is a lot of replayability. If you like crime stories, if you liked the Tell Tale games, or if you just want to support indie devs making amazing games then buy this game!

reviewText:
Short version: 84%The Detail is a gritty crime story motion comic, presented as a lightweight adventure game/interactive movie. The lack of voice acting really hurts, but the story more than makes up for it.

Long version:The Detail is an episodic adventure game made by upstart Finnish developer Rival Games (who take marketing way too seriously for a company of their size and portfolio).

Episode 1: Where the Dead Lie strikes a balance between semi-realistic police dramas and hard-boiled crime stories. The characters, including the two protagonists– an aging, no-nonsense homicide cop and an ex-criminal who finally got his life straight– feel real, although the plot is more movie-like.
The largest contributor to the atmosphere is the motion comic presentation, which follows French comic albums in design. The art style is strong at the beginning, but later stages feel rushed, especially when it comes to faces.

The Detail follows TellTale’s interactive movie format, so don’t expect any actual gameplay elements. There are a few dialogue choices to change some details, but eventually all lead to the same results. This also means that while this first episode is promising, it doesn’t offer too much to judge what the series can lead into.

reviewText:
The Detail is a crime noir adventure with a similar style to The Walking Dead and other telltale games.  I thought I was finished with this type of game, but The Detail offered me much more than The Wolf Among Us or The Walking Dead and it managed this through this first episode.  It does grab you from the get go and leaves you wanting more.

It's another game where your choices apparently matter and of course the full extent of these choices will not be noticeable until further episodes are released in the future.  However, I played through this episode 3 times and each playthrough was quite different in some clever ways.  In one I was a brutal cop who would beat a suspect and the next time I was pleading with him and offering deals to get information.  It just seemed like it wasn't your standard 'Pick A or B' like many of these games use.

The lack of voice overs is a minor problem, but it still felt quite atmospheric.  The graphical style is great and certain scenes ooze atmosphere and style.  Some of the game feels like a comic and other parts feel like a classic detective noir movie.  It's a very promising start to the series.

If you enjoyed the likes of The Walking Dead and The Wolf Among Us then you really should try this out.  It's different enough and I think it offers something more.  Each scene is important, it has a good pace and should leave you desperate for the 2nd installment to see what is going to happen.  Plenty of replay value if you decide you want to just try things in a different way.

reviewText:
The Detail, developed by Rival Games Ltd, puts you into the shoes of a detective who is about to be handed one hell of a case that will change everything in the city. I know this is a slight spoiler, but a gang boss is found executed. Was it a drug deal gone wrong, was it a hired hit, why are all the drugs still at the scene? You will have to answer all of these questions and more. The interesting thing about this game is that it is definitely a point and click adventure, but there are definitely points that can definitely go in different directions. Now of course it still has a concrete start and finish, but this game actually allows you the chance of making different actions take different effects in the end.

Graphically this game looks pretty good, the one thing that does seem a bit off is the walking from front to back, I don't know what it is but it looks off. Now one of my favorite things in a point and click adventure game is the ability to toggle on and off all the interactive spots in an area. The developers do a great job of doing this, with highlighting the areas with an orange circle or arrow, as well as a greyed out circle or arrow for things you have previously interacted with. You will also get to see a wide variety of locations in this game, which to me is especially impressive seeing as the game isn't all that long and doesn't really reuse most of the scenes. I'm also a fan of the character design found in the game, you are going to see people of all different stature, race, gender, and age. Once again quite impressive when you think about the short length of this first chapter of the game.

Alright now comes the ONE portion of the game that left me screaming in frustration. The sounds and music of the game. This is supposed to have intense moments, but none of it felt intense. The music didn't really draw the player in, and the lack of voice work causes me great distress. How could a game that looks this well put together miss out so totally on one of the key components of a game?

The controls are what you would think for a point and click adventure game. Well almost, you see there is some tension and concentration that is introduced into the game when you are taking part in an action scene. No you don't have to worry about button combos, but you will have to make split second decisions, and in some instances you will have to get the timing just right.

So here's the deal, the game starts off with decisions in which whatever you choose could bare consequences to the story. The thing is you have to live with them as you go along. Now that being said this definitely allows for a unique chance of actually playing the game again and having slightly different outcomes occur. It is very rare for me, personally, to see an episodic, point and click adventure game, where there's actually replayability, and its not just to do something obscure, you can actually re-write a chunk of the game's middle portion. You are also going to get the chance to play more than just the detective in this game, which will definitely enhance the story that you will find yourself in.

This game is definitely not meant for all ages, but it is something that I think everyone should at least check out. I just really wish that there was voice acting in this game. The problem is that I know that there are those out there who are going to bee turned off with that amount of reading required to get the whole story. Sure there are parts in cut-scenes, and in situations where you have to make a decision, that perhaps voice acting would not completely fit, but there needs to be something, and in the end you're going to be left wanting. The strange thing is that its a 50/50 split between wanting to hear more than the forgettable background music, and wanting to know what happens next in the game. So in the end I've got to give this game a 7.4 out of 10 (It could have been much higher with better sound).

reviewText:
The game is developed by these people... http://rival-games.com/team if you have clicked the link you will notice that most of the developers hide their face. For good reason, I would hide it too if i created this lacklustre production. The detail is an interactive graphic novel with very limited interaction needed. It apparently will have 5 episodes in total, 2 of which have been released and the next three will have a gap inbetween. If that is not enough to put you to sleep, the story in this game should do the trick.

The developers have chosen to feature several people's timelines in the hope that they will branch together in the end. There is so many timelines and characters, that no character development is spent on one, therefore your care factor on them is zero. If they all were to injest rat poison and end the series quicker you'd probably cheer.

To make matters worse there is no voice acting, hence you have to read everything to characters you wish would go play with a ceiling fan. The developers have stated that no voice acting is better than cheap voice acting. WHAT A LOAD OF KIBBOSH!!! There are literally hundreds of examples of developers who have voiced their own products and done decent jobs on it. Your a big company aren't you? Surely you have enough money for a microphone? Surely you know how you would like your characters to sound wouldn't you? Stop cutting corners. Give us a GOOD product.

I must admit that they have produced some pleasant eyecatching detailed cartoons especially in the first episode, but all that falls back to a bland, uninspiring example in the second episode. Episode 2 basically just follows the same layed out format as episode 1, hence nothing comes to a surprise. There is even less interaction needed in episode 2 other than to find out where to click next. Very little intellegence needed to get through this graphic novel. In fact i was even able to pass this whole thing by falling asleep and resting my head on the keyboard.

While this review is extremely negative, I really wish it wasn't. They have a good idea here, but it's just rather humdrum in it's execution. Hence the money they are asking for is no way on this planet is worth it. There are way better products out there for the same buck. With one third of the people who have bought this complaining that this story is dull and cheesed off that there is no voice acting, i really hope that these Finland developers put a firecracker on their chair, start spicing up episode 3 and go out and splash out on a microphone...

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game. I usually enjoy these kind of adventure games, and the story seemed interesting and targeted to a grown up player. But somehow I can´t get around to giving it a thumbs up. I would say it is worth a try and that maybe you´ll like it, but all in all I wouldn´t recommend it.

The major flaw to me was that this game felt slow. I´m not speaking of troubleshooting, I´m speaking of the pace of the story itself. You have to do most things in a certain order, and if you´re thinking one step ahead you might feel like you´re being held back. The story had potential but its developement and the dialogues didn´t make it worth the being held back feeling. It just felt slow and a bit superficial (like all the coroner´s exchange).
I didn´t really like any of the characters either, as -in my opinion- they were also rather superficial and stereotyped. The story had potential, but it just followed the path of so many cop-tales before it.
The graphs were ok, nothing to write back home about, but adequate to the storyline and the mood. The backgrounds were what I found better accomplished.
I didn´t really like the soundtrack, it wasn´t noir enough, it wasn´t blue enough, it was somewhere in the middle. Same goes for the choices and the action parts: They were nothing special, the action itself was pretty lame and scarce.

Owning the game I might -might- give it another go to see if different choices make the story look better, or to see how easy it is to get all the Steam achievements. But being this a story one has to buy per episode (and since you can complete each episode in under 2 hours) I don´t think I´ll even check the future episodes.

To sum up, I didn´t really like it because I found it un-engaging and slow. But would not discourage you from giving it a go if you can find a good price or free demo so you can decide if it´s worth the investment first. I still think The Wolf Among Us was far better in all aspects.

Your choices matter, in as far as the responses you get feel human and reactive, but only until the next scene and then it's roughly the same as if you didn't make a choice. I felt like my choices were there for achievements and getting different newspaper prints at the end about my choices.

This is very much an interactive story, don't expect to actually be solving crimes in this or uncovering clues, you just kind of follow the story path and make decisions. Treat it as a dating sim in terms of gameplay (Not a bad thing, just as a comparison) There are a few small timed minigames, but they have short term effects and don't really change the outcome.

Overall the dialogue is entertaining to read and interesting, but it does have its moments where you roll your eyes at the generic lines and sentences from some characters. Namely Joe (Man in orange and blue jacket) who puts me to sleep sometimes.

Art and the visuals are quite varied, can be really nice comic book style, or something I might put on the fridge with a magnet. The game always takes itself seriously (which is perfectly fine), but occasionally some faces make me laugh when they appear.

I know this is just a single episode of 5, and that makes it difficult to make criticisms, but at the same time this is an individually purchasable game in itself. I think it's not enough for the asking price. I don't think it's entirely worth replaying, but it does have some variations as the game moves on.

I recommend it, but not for the launch price of $5.99.

reviewText:
The Detail

Pros:
- Fast paced gameplay
- Fast paced narrative
- Casual pick up and enjoy game, great for busy lives in need of quick escapism
- Replay value for achievements and gameplay decision options
- Fantastic art style
- Perfect mood setting musical score
- The stereotypical characters are developed well to become interesting in the round

Cons:
- The raw gameplay derives more from dialogue or action options rather than traditional point and click puzzles
- Lack of traditional systems like verb icons or inventory mean the gameplay lacks depth (but this does not mean the narrative lacks depth)
- The lack of episodes is the real problem

Overall:
- The hybrid visual novel/point and click hybrid allows the narrative to take centre stage. There is no turning back due to the comic book style narrative.
- This also means there is no room for endless backtracking talking to NPCs over and over and no fidgetting with inventory items wondering what to do next. Thats a good thing though. The endless backtracking and fidgetting really only works in comedy point and click games with humorous exchanges rather than in serious toned games where you just become frustrated if you can't progress
- I did find that the game only let the player do the raw policework but did not let the player solve" any of the clues or policework. The characters often solved it for you or automatically explained what a clue meant etc.
- The biggest downside is that so much is put into the narrative that it works almost too well. Episode 1 really does feel like a pilot episode of a really engaging crime noir series. Then you realise only two episodes are available!
